wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty Gap ($1.25 a day)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under Middle Class ($10 a day) Gap

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to electricity (% of total population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Global Electrification Database 2012

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total final energy consumption (TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total final energy consumption (TFEC): This indicator is derived form energy balances statistics and is equivalent to total final consumption excluding non-energy use.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, youth total (% of people ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The number of persons aged 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. For further country-specific definition details please refer to the source of information, the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS): www.uis.unesco.org
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source of information: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (www.uis.unesco.org). Please refer to its website for country-specific details on the specific national data sources and method used.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to electricity (% of rural population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to electricity is the percentage of rural population with access to electricity.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Global Electrification Database 2013

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to electricity (% of urban population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to electricity is the percentage of total population with access to electricity.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Global Electrification Database 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy savings of primary energy (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy savings of primary energy (TJ): Energy savings due to realized energy intensity improvements. Country level savings represent the difference between a hypothetical energy consumption that would have been should the energy intensity remained at its 1990 level and actual consumption. Global, regional and income group savings represent the sum of country by country savings and not calculated separately.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Thermal efficiency (%) in power supply
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Thermal efficiency (%) in power supply: This supply-side energy efficiency indicator measure the efficiency of thermal plants in converting primary energy sources—such as coal, gas, and oil—into electricity. They are calculated by dividing gross electricity production from electricity and cogeneration plants by total inputs of fuels into those plants. Whether market-based or privately owned, self-generating plants that do not export their power are included in the index assessment. In the case of cogeneration plants, fuel inputs are allocated between electricity and heat production in proportion to their shares of the annual output.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transmission and distribution losses (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transmission and distribution losses (%): Transmission and distribution (T&D) losses measure power lost in the transmission of (high-voltage) electricity from power generators to distributors and in the distribution of (medium- and low-voltage) electricity from distributors to end-users. T&D losses are represented as a percentage of gross electricity production. They include both technical and nontechnical (or commercial) losses. Included in the latter are unmetered, unbilled, and unpaid electricity, including theft, which could be significant in developing countries. Aggregate T&D system indicators may be dominated by factors other than losses. The location of primary energy resources (such as hydro lakes and coal seams) and large loads (cities and industries) may be more significant factors in T&D efficiency indicators than the losses or efficiency of the transmission system itself. Properly separating true losses (and hence the efficiency potential of transmission systems) from exogenous location and scale factors and nontechnical losses would require detailed studies of system-dynamic interactions and real operating requirements that are not practical for global tracking purposes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy intensity of industrial sector (MJ/$2005)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy intensity of industrial sector (MJ/$2005): A ratio between energy consumption in industry (including energy industry own use) and industry sector value added measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output. Lower ratio indicates that less energy is used to produce one unit of output.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy intensity of agricultural sector (MJ/$2005)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy intensity of agricultural sector (MJ/$2005): A ratio between energy consumption in agricultural sector (including forestry and fishing) and agricultural sector value added measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output. Lower ratio indicates that less energy is used to produce one unit of output.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy intensity of other sectors (MJ/$2005)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy intensity of other sectors (MJ/$2005): A ratio between energy consumption in other sectors (including services, residential and transport) and services sector value added measured at purchasing power parity. Energy intensity is an indication of how much energy is used to produce one unit of economic output. Lower ratio indicates that less energy is used to produce one unit of output.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Energy Intensity component Index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Index is created from the series of year to year Energy Intensity component of the Decomposition Analysis with the DIVISIA LMDI I method. The Significant Period is defined as the period for which the available data is consistent in the energy and value added databases such that all the sectors have energy and value added for those years. The CAGR is calculated over that Significant Period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Activity component Index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Index is created from the series of year to year Activity component of the Decomposition Analysis with the DIVISIA LMDI I method. The Significant Period is defined as the period for which the available data is consistent in the energy and value added databases such that all the sectors have energy and value added for those years. The CAGR is calculated over that Significant Period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Structure Component Index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Index is created from the series of year to year Structure component of the Decomposition Analysis with the DIVISIA LMDI I method. The Significant Period is defined as the period for which the available data is consistent in the energy and value added databases such that all the sectors have energy and value added for those years. The CAGR is calculated over that Significant Period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Energy Intensity component -Compound Annual Growth Rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of the Energy Intensity component calculated over the significant period
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Activity component - Compound Annual Growth Rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of the Activity component calculated over the significant period
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Divisia Decomposition Analysis - Structure Component - Compound Annual Growth Rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of the Structure component calculated over the significant period
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: HOI: Completing 6th grade on time
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: HOI: Mathematics Proficiency Level 2
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, region of school location, father's occupation, and a household wealth index based on assets.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations using PISA Data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: National accounts base year
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It is being looked back 10 years starting the year before actual year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Consumer price index base year
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It is being looked back 10 years starting the year before actual year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Balance of payments manual in use
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Country has adopted either one of the two latest editions (BPM5 or BPM6)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Traditional biomass consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Traditional biomass consumption (% in TFEC): Share of traditional biomass in total final energy consumption. Traditional biomass is defined as biomass consumed in the residential sector in non-OECD countries. It includes the following categories in the IEA statistics: primary solid biofuels, charcoal and non-specified primary biofuels and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Marine energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Marine energy consumption (% in TFEC): Share of marine energy in total final consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Modern biomass consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Modern biomass consumption (% in TFEC): Share of modern biomass in total final energy consumption. Modern biomass is defined as all biomass that was not consumed in the residential sector in non-OECD countries. It includes the following categories in the IEA statistics: primary solid biofuels, charcoal and non-specified primary biofuels and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Hydro energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Hydro consumption (% in TFEC): Share of hydro energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Liquid biofuels consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Liquid biofuels consumption (% in TFEC): Share of liquid biofuels energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wind energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wind consumption (% in TFEC): Share of wind energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Solar energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Solar consumption (% in TFEC): Share of solar energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Geothermal energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Geothermal consumption (% in TFEC): Share of geothermal energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Waste energy consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Waste energy consumption (% in TFEC): Share of waste energy in total final consumption, which is defined in the IEA statistics as renewable municipal waste
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Biogas consumption (% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Biogas consumption (% in TFEC): Share of biogas in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to Non-Solid Fuel (% of total population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to Non-Solid Fuel is the percentage of population with access to Non-Solid Fuel.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Global Household Energy Database 2012

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrolment, preprimary, national source (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pre-Primary Gross Enrolment Rate (GER): The number of pupils enrolled in pre-primary school, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population in the theoretical age group in pre-primary school. The purpose of this indicator is to measure the general level of participation of children in Early Childhood Education (ECE) programs. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Renewable energy consumption(% in TFEC)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Renewable energy consumption(% in TFEC): Share of renewables energy in total final energy consumption
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to Non-Solid Fuel (% of rural population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to Non-Solid Fuel is the percentage of rural population with access to Non-Solid Fuel.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Global Household Energy Database 2013

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross intake ratio in grade 1, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross intake ratio (GIR): This indicator measures the total number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population at the official primary school-entrance age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to Non-Solid Fuel (% of urban population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to Non-Solid Fuel is the percentage of total population with access to Non-Solid Fuel.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Global Household Energy Database 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio in grade 1
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male values of gross intake ratio for primary first grade. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rate of out of school children, national source (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of children of official primary school age who are not enrolled in primary or secondary school, expressed as a percentage of the population of official primary school age. This indicator is intended to measure the size of the population in the official primary school age range that should be targeted by policies and efforts to achieve universal primary education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary completion rate, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Primary Completion Rate (PCR) is the percentage of pupils who completed the last year of primary schooling. It is computed by dividing the total number of students in the last grade of primary school minus repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official completing age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for primary completion rate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male values of Primary Completion Rate. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Progression to secondary school, national source (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This indicator measures the number of new entrants to the first grade of secondary education (general programs only) in a given year, expressed as a percentage of the number of pupils enrolled in the final grade of primary education in the previous year. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary completion rate, total, national source (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The lower secondary school completion rate is the percentage of children who are completing the last year of lower secondary education. It is computed by dividing the total number of students in the last grade of lower secondary education school minus repeaters in that grade divided by the total number of children of official completing age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Atkinson, A(.5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Atkinson, A(1)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Atkinson, A(2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Generalized Entrophy, GE(-1)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Generalized Entrophy, GE(2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gini Coefficient
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation includes observations of 0 income.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gini Coefficient (No Zero Income)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation does not includes observations of 0 income.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income Share of First Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of household income held by the bottom quintile (0-20 percent).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income Share of Second Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of household income held by the seocnd quintile (20 - 40 percent).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income Share of Third Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of household income held by the third quintile (40 - 60 percent).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income Share of Fourth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of household income held by the fourth quintile (60 - 80 percent).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income Share of Fifth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of household income held by the top quintile (80 - 100 percent).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mean Log Deviation, GE(0)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rate 75/25
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The decile dispersion ratio presents the ratio of the average income of the richest 25 percent by that of the poorest 25 percent. This ratio expresses the income of the top quantile as multiples of that of the poorest quantile. However, it ignores information about incomes in the middle of the income distribution and doesn’t use information about the distribution of income within the top and bottom deciles or percentiles.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rate 90/10
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The decile dispersion ratio presents the ratio of the average income of the richest 10 percent by that of the poorest 10 percent. This ratio expresses the income of the top quantile as multiples of that of the poorest quantile. However, it ignores information about incomes in the middle of the income distribution and doesn’t use information about the distribution of income within the top and bottom deciles or percentiles.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Theil Index, GE(1)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Theil index is part of a larger family of measures referred to as the General Entropy class. Compared to the Gini index, it has the advantage of being additive across different subgroups or regions in the country. However, it does not have a straightforward representation and lacks the appealing interpretation of the Gini coefficient.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural census
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Looking at 10 year interval starting the year before current and counting the number of agricultural censuses conducted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government finance accounting
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Government finance data have been consolidated into one account capturing all central government's fiscal activities. Consolidated accounts for central government in place.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Traditional biomass consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Traditional biomass consumption (TJ): Final consumption of traditional biomass. Traditional biomass is defined as biomass consumed in the residential sector in non-OECD countries. It includes the following categories in the IEA statistics: primary solid biofuels, charcoal and non-specified primary biofuels and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Marine energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Marine energy consumption (TJ): Final consumption of marine energy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Modern biomass consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Modern biomass consumption (% in TFEC): Final consumption of modern biomass. Modern biomass is defined as all biomass that was not consumed in the residential sector in non-OECD countries. It includes the following categories in the IEA statistics: primary solid biofuels, charcoal and non-specified primary biofuels and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Hydro energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Hydro consumption (TJ): Final consumption of hydro energy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Liquid biofuels consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Liquid biofuels consumption (TJ): Final consumption of liquid biofuels, including biogasoline, biodiesels and other liquid biofuels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wind energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wind consumption (TJ): Final consumption of wind energy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Solar energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Solar consumption (TJ): Final consumption of solar energy, including solar PV and solar thermal
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Geothermal energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Geothermal consumption (TJ): Final consumption of geothermal energy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Waste energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Waste energy consumption (TJ): Final consumption of waste energy, which is defined in the IEA statistics as renewable municipal waste
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Biogas consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Biogas consumption (TJ): Final consumption of biogas
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gini, Rural
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation includes observations of 0 income.

For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Theil Index, GE(1), Rural

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary education, new teachers, national source
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Persons employed for the first time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in lower secondary school, excluding educational personnel who have no active teaching duties. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, new entrants, national source
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pupils entering primary school for the first time, excluding repetears. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.

It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Renewable energy consumption (TJ)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Renewable energy consumption (TJ): This indicator includes renewable energy consumption of all technologies: hydro, modern and traditional biomass, wind, solar, liquid biofuels, biogas, geothermal, marine and waste
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population census

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vital registration system coverage
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: There should be a complete vital registration system (birth and death) in place within the last 15 years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary education, classrooms, national source

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary education, pupils, national source
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total population of pupils in lower secondary school, regardless of age. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary education, teachers, national source
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Persons employed in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils in lower secondary school, excluding educational personnel who have no active teaching duties. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total electricity output (GWh)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total electricity output (GWh): Total number of GWh generated by all power plants
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Renewable energy electricity output (GWh)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Renewable energy electricity output (GWh): Total number of GWh generated by renewable power plants, including wind, solar PV, solar thermal, hydro, marine, geothermal, biomass, renewable municipal waste, liquid biofuels and biogas. Electricity production for hydro pumpted storage is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public spending on total education (% of total public spending)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenses devoted to the education sector, including recurrent and capital expenditures and teacher salaries, expressed as a percentage of the total general government expenses. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public spending on basic education (% of public spending on total education)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenses devoted to the basic education sector, including recurrent and capital expenditures and teacher salaries, expressed as a percentage of the public spending on total education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public recurrent spending on total education (% of total public recurrent spending)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public recurrent expenses devoted to the education sector, expressed as a percentage of the total general government recurrent expenses. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public recurrent spending on basic education (% of public recurrent spending on total education)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public recurrent expenses devoted to the basic education sector, expressed as a percentage of the public recurrent spending on total education. Country-specific definition, method and targets are determined by countries themselves.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data were collected from national and other publicly available sources, and validated by the Local Education Group (LEG) in each country. LEGs are typically led by the Ministry of Education and include development partners and other education stakeholders. Data were not processed or analyzed by the Global Partnership for Education. It is reported as it was presented in the original sources, or as it was communicated to us through the Coordinating Agency or Lead Donor of the LEG.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annualized Mean Income Growth (2003-2012)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The official indicator to monitor shared prosperity is the growth in real per capita income (or consumption) of the bottom 40 percent of the income (or consumption) distribution in a country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank) and World Development Indicators

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annualized Mean Income Growth Bottom 40 Percent (2003-2012)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The indicator to monitor shared prosperity is the growth in real per capita income (or consumption) of the bottom 40 percent of the income (or consumption) distribution in a country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank) and World Development Indicators

wb:indicator.wb:name: Shared Prosperity Convergence Indicator (SPCI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The SPCI measures the gap between the Sen’s Welfare Index (GDP per capita adjusted by income inequality) for any given country with respect to the average Sen’s index of the top ten global performers. The SPCI is based on the Sen’s Welfare Index (Sen 1976), which is calculated as the mean income (y) times one minus the Gini coefficient (G), that is, SPCI=y(G-1) The Sen’s Welfare Index benchmark is 23,535 (equity-adjusted per capita GDP per year, PPP 2005), derived from the population-weighted average of the Sen’s Welfare Index of the top ten countries in 2000 (Luxembourg, Qatar, Norway, Denmark, United States, Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Canada and Singapore).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank) and World Development Indicators.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industrial production index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Look 8 years back starting 3 years before current year
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: External debt reporting status
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Actual or preliminary reporting status
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Import and export price indexes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Look 8 years back starting 3 years before current year
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: International aid disbursed to total education, CIDA to Afghanistan (USD million)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International concessional aid disbursed by the reporting development partner to the total education sector in the specific developing country. Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The 2011 Monitoring Exercise on Aid Effectiveness in the Education Sector was produced by the Global Partnership for Education in parallel to the OECD’s 2011 Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration. Through this exercise participating donors reported on the international aid allocated and projected to specific developing countries. Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/

Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/

Targets indicate scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The 2011 Monitoring Exercise on Aid Effectiveness in the Education Sector was produced by the Global Partnership for Education in parallel to the OECD’s 2011 Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration. Through this exercise participating donors reported on the international aid allocated and projected to specific developing countries. Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annualized Mean Income Growth (2003-2007)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The indicator to monitor shared prosperity is the growth in real per capita income (or consumption) of the bottom 40 percent of the income (or consumption) distribution in a country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank) and World Development Indicators

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annualized Mean Income Growth Bottom 40 Percent (2003-2007)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The indicator to monitor shared prosperity is the growth in real per capita income (or consumption) of the bottom 40 percent of the income (or consumption) distribution in a country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank) and World Development Indicators

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of renewable capacity in total capacity (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of renewable capacity in total capacity (%): Share of renewable energy capacity in total istalled capacity
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: International aid for total education, disbursed (up to present year) and scheduled (next years), aggregation of reporting donors (USD million)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Sum of international concessional aid disbursed by reporting development partners (donors) to the total education sector in a specific developing country. Targets indicate the sum of the scheduled or projected aid. Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by donors to the Global Partnership for Education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The 2011 Monitoring Exercise on Aid Effectiveness in the Education Sector was produced by the Global Partnership for Education (GPE) in parallel to the OECD’s 2011 Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration. Through this exercise participating donors reported on the international aid allocated and projected to specific developing countries. Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/

wb:indicator.wb:name: UNESCO reporting
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It will be looked at the 4-year-period starting 2 years back from actual year (e.g. for 2012: Years 2007-10).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health survey
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Looking at 10 year interval starting the year before current and counting the number of health surveys conducted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: National immunization coverage
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It will be looked at the 4 most recent years with data available. The average of WHO/UNICEF estimate and government (official) data needs to be <=1.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty survey
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Looking at 10 year interval starting the year before current and counting the number of poverty surveys conducted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/

Accounted aid includes activities, projects, technical cooperation and sector and budget support (20%), as it was reported by the donor to the Global Partnership for Education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The 2011 Monitoring Exercise on Aid Effectiveness in the Education Sector was produced by the Global Partnership for Education in parallel to the OECD’s 2011 Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration. Through this exercise participating donors reported on the international aid allocated and projected to specific developing countries. Data were later validated and/or updated when preparing the GPE Results Report in 2012. Most of the figures were reported in 2011 and in USD. When it was not the case, currencies were converted to USD. Data are relative to a calendar year, unless it is specified otherwise in the country notes. For further details in this 2012 Monitoring Exercise, please refer to the following web site: http://www.globalpartnership.org/our-work/areas-of-focus/aid-effectiveness/2011-monitoring-exercise-on-aid-effectiveness-2/
