wb:indicator.wb:name: Wood charcoal production quantity (tonnes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wood carbonized by partial combustion or application of heat from an external source. It is used as a fuel or for other uses. Figures are given in weight (MT).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wood fuel production quantity (CUM, solid volume units)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wood fuel refers to all roundwood used as fuel for purposes such as cooking, heating, or power production. It includes wood harvested from main stems, branches and other parts of trees. It also includes wood intended for charcoal production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural land (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded. Land under permanent crops is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber. Permanent pasture is land used for five or more years for forage, including natural and cultivated crops.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural land (sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded. Land under permanent crops is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber. Permanent pasture is land used for five or more years for forage, including natural and cultivated crops.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural land (% of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded. Land under permanent crops is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber. Permanent pasture is land used for five or more years for forage, including natural and cultivated crops.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Arable land (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Arable land (in hectares) includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Arable land (hectares per person)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Arable land (hectares per person) includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Arable land (% of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under barley production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under barley production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cereal cropland (% of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under cereal production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, Production Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under cereal production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under cereal production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Permanent cropland (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Permanent cropland is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Permanent cropland (% of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Permanent cropland is land cultivated with crops that occupy the land for long periods and need not be replanted after each harvest, such as cocoa, coffee, and rubber. This category includes land under flowering shrubs, fruit trees, nut trees, and vines, but excludes land under trees grown for wood or timber.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Arable and permanent cropland (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This land category is the sum of areas under “Arable land” and "Permanent crops”. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land area where elevation is below 5 meters (% of total land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land area below 5m is the percentage of total land where the elevation is 5 meters or less.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN), Place II dataset.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under fonio production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under fonio production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Forest area (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Forest area is land under natural or planted stands of trees of at least 5 meters in situ, whether productive or not, and excludes tree stands in agricultural production systems (for example, in fruit plantations and agroforestry systems) and trees in urban parks and gardens.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Forest area (sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Forest area is land under natural or planted stands of trees of at least 5 meters in situ, whether productive or not, and excludes tree stands in agricultural production systems (for example, in fruit plantations and agroforestry systems) and trees in urban parks and gardens.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Forest area (% of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Forest area is land under natural or planted stands of trees of at least 5 meters in situ, whether productive or not, and excludes tree stands in agricultural production systems (for example, in fruit plantations and agroforestry systems) and trees in urban parks and gardens.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural irrigated land (% of total agricultural land)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural irrigated land refers to agricultural areas purposely provided with water, including land irrigated by controlled flooding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural area irrigated (ha)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural area irrigated, part of the full or partial control irrigated agricultural land which is actually irrigated in a given year. Often, part of the equipped area is not irrigated for various reasons, such as lack of water, absence of farmers, land degradation, damage, organisational problems etc.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land area equipped for irrigation (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Area equipped to provide water (via irrigation) to the crops. It includes areas equipped for full and partial control irrigation, equipped lowland areas, pastures, and areas equipped for spate irrigation. Data are expressed in 1000 hectares.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under millet production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under millet production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under maize production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under maize production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Average precipitation in depth (mm per year)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average precipitation is the long-term average in depth (over space and time) of annual precipitation in the country. Precipitation is defined as any kind of water that falls from clouds as a liquid or a solid.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under rice production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under rice production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under sorghum production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under sorghum production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land area (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land area (sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural machinery, tractors per 100 sq. km of arable land
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Land under wheat production (hectares)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Land under wheat production refers to harvested area, although some countries report only sown or cultivated area. Production data on relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture production index (1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The FAO indices of agricultural production show the relative level of the aggregate volume of agricultural production for each year in comparison with the base period 2004-2006. They are based on the sum of price-weighted quantities of different agricultural commodities produced after deductions of quantities used as seed and feed weighted in a similar manner. The resulting aggregate represents, therefore, disposable production for any use except as seed and feed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Barley production (metric tons)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Production data on barley relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cereal production (metric tons)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cereal production index (1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cereal production index covers cereals that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. The FAO indices of agricultural production show the relative level of the aggregate volume of agricultural production for each year in comparison with the base period 2004-2006. They are based on the sum of price-weighted quantities of different agricultural commodities produced after deductions of quantities used as seed and feed weighted in a similar manner. The resulting aggregate represents, therefore, disposable production for any use except as seed and feed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Crop production index (2004-2006 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Crop production index shows agricultural production for each year relative to the base period 2004-2006. It includes all crops except fodder crops. Regional and income group aggregates for the FAO's production indexes are calculated from the underlying values in international dollars, normalized to the base period 2004-2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fonio production (metric tons)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Production data on fonio relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food production index (2004-2006 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food production index covers food crops that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. Coffee and tea are excluded because, although edible, they have no nutritive value.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The FAO indices of agricultural production show the relative level of the aggregate volume of agricultural production for each year in comparison with the base period 2004-2006. They are based on the sum of price-weighted quantities of different agricultural commodities produced after deductions of quantities used as seed and feed weighted in a similar manner. The resulting aggregate represents, therefore, disposable production for any use except as seed and feed. All the indices at the country, regional and world levels are calculated by the Laspeyres formula. Production quantities of each commodity are weighted by 2004-2006 average international commodity prices and summed for each year. To obtain the index, the aggregate for a given year is divided by the average aggregate for the base period 2004-2006. Since the FAO indices are based on the concept of agriculture as a single enterprise, amounts of seed and feed are subtracted from the production data to avoid double counting them, once in the production data and once with the crops or livestock produced from them. Deductions for seed (in the case of eggs, for hatching) and for livestock and poultry feed apply to both domestically produced and imported commodities. They cover only primary agricultural products destined to animal feed (e.g. maize, potatoes, milk, etc.). Processed and semi-processed feed items such as bran, oilcakes, meals and molasses have been completely excluded from the calculations at all stages. should be noted that when calculating indices of agricultural, food and nonfood production, all intermediate primary inputs of agricultural origin are deducted. However, for indices of any other commodity group, only inputs originating from within the same group are deducted; thus, only seed is removed from the group “crops” and from all crop subgroups, such as cereals, oil crops, etc.; and both feed and seed originating from within the livestock sector (e.g. milk feed, hatching eggs) are removed from the group “livestock products”. For the main two livestock subgroups, namely, meat and milk, only feed originating from the respective subgroup is removed. The ”international commodity prices” are used in order to avoid the use of exchange rates for obtaining continental and world aggregates, and also to improve and facilitate international comparative analysis of productivity at the national level. These” international prices”, expressed in so-called ""international dollars”, are derived using a Geary-Khamis formula for the agricultural sector. This method assigns a single “price” to each commodity. For example, one metric ton of wheat has the same price regardless of the country where it was produced. The currency unit in which the prices are expressed has no influence on the indices published. The commodities covered in the computation of indices of agricultural production are all crops and livestock products originating in each country. Practically all products are covered, with the main exception of fodder crops. The category of food production includes commodities that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. Accordingly, coffee and tea are excluded along with inedible commodities because, although edible, they have practically no nutritive value. Aggregates are the sum of available data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cereal production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cereal production index covers cereals that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. The FAO indices of agricultural production show the relative level of the aggregate volume of agricultural production for each year in comparison with the base period 2004-2006. They are based on the sum of price-weighted quantities of different agricultural commodities produced after deductions of quantities used as seed and feed weighted in a similar manner. The resulting aggregate represents, therefore, disposable production for any use except as seed and feed. All the indices at the country, regional and world levels are calculated by the Laspeyres formula. Production quantities of each commodity are weighted by 2004-2006 average international commodity prices and summed for each year. To obtain the index, the aggregate for a given year is divided by the average aggregate for the base period 2004-2006. Since the FAO indices are based on the concept of agriculture as a single enterprise, amounts of seed and feed are subtracted from the production data to avoid double counting them, once in the production data and once with the crops or livestock produced from them. Deductions for seed (in the case of eggs, for hatching) and for livestock and poultry feed apply to both domestically produced and imported commodities. They cover only primary agricultural products destined to animal feed (e.g. maize, potatoes, milk, etc.). Processed and semi-processed feed items such as bran, oilcakes, meals and molasses have been completely excluded from the calculations at all stages. should be noted that when calculating indices of agricultural, food and nonfood production, all intermediate primary inputs of agricultural origin are deducted. However, for indices of any other commodity group, only inputs originating from within the same group are deducted; thus, only seed is removed from the group “crops” and from all crop subgroups, such as cereals, oil crops, etc.; and both feed and seed originating from within the livestock sector (e.g. milk feed, hatching eggs) are removed from the group “livestock products”. For the main two livestock subgroups, namely, meat and milk, only feed originating from the respective subgroup is removed. The ”international commodity prices” are used in order to avoid the use of exchange rates for obtaining continental and world aggregates, and also to improve and facilitate international comparative analysis of productivity at the national level. These” international prices”, expressed in so-called ""international dollars”, are derived using a Geary-Khamis formula for the agricultural sector. This method assigns a single “price” to each commodity. For example, one metric ton of wheat has the same price regardless of the country where it was produced. The currency unit in which the prices are expressed has no influence on the indices published. The commodities covered in the computation of indices of agricultural production are all crops and livestock products originating in each country. Practically all products are covered, with the main exception of fodder crops. The category of food production includes commodities that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. Accordingly, coffee and tea are excluded along with inedible commodities because, although edible, they have practically no nutritive value. Aggregates are the sum of available data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Crop production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Crop production index shows agricultural production for each year relative to the base period 2004-2006. It includes all crops except fodder crops. Regional and income group aggregates for the FAO's production indexes are calculated from the underlying values in international dollars, normalized to the base period 2004-2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food production index covers food crops that are considered edible and that contain nutrients. Coffee and tea are excluded because, although edible, they have no nutritive value.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Livestock production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Livestock production index includes meat and milk from all sources, dairy products such as cheese, and eggs, honey, raw silk, wool, and hides and skins.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Non-food production index (gross, 1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Non-food production index covers non-food items. All the indices at the country, regional and world levels are calculated by the Laspeyres formula. Production quantities of each commodity are weighted by 2004-2006 average international commodity prices and summed for each year. To obtain the index, the aggregate for a given year is divided by the average aggregate for the base period 2004-2006. It should be noted that when calculating indices of agricultural, food and nonfood production, all intermediate primary inputs of agricultural origin are deducted. However, for indices of any other commodity group, only inputs originating from within the same group are deducted; thus, only seed is removed from the group “crops” and from all crop subgroups, such as cereals, oil crops, etc.; and both feed and seed originating from within the livestock sector (e.g. milk feed, hatching eggs) are removed from the group “livestock products”. For the main two livestock subgroups, namely, meat and milk, only feed originating from the respective subgroup is removed. The ""international commodity prices” are used in order to avoid the use of exchange rates for obtaining continental and world aggregates, and also to improve and facilitate international comparative analysis of productivity at the national level. These” international prices”, expressed in so-called ""international dollars”, are derived using a Geary-Khamis formula for the agricultural sector. This method assigns a single “price” to each commodity. For example, one metric ton of wheat has the same price regardless of the country where it was produced. The currency unit in which the prices are expressed has no influence on the indices published. The indices are calculated from production data presented on a calendar year basis. Aggregates are the sum of available data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, Production Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Livestock production index (2004-2006 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Livestock production index includes meat and milk from all sources, dairy products such as cheese, and eggs, honey, raw silk, wool, and hides and skins.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Production data on millet relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Production data on maize relate to crop harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross non-food production index (1999-2001 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Non-food production index covers non-food items. They are based on the sum of price-weighted quantities of different agricultural commodities produced after deductions of quantities used as seed and feed weighted in a similar manner. wb:indicator.wb:name: Barley seed quantity (FAO, metric tonnes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Data include the amounts of the commodity in question set aside for sowing or planting (or generally for reproduction purposes, e.g. sugar cane planted, potatoes for seed, eggs for hatching and fish for bait, whether domestically produced or imported) during the reference period. Account is taken of double or successive sowing or planting whenever it occurs. The data of seed include also, when it is the case, the quantities necessary for sowing or planting the area relating to crops harvested green for fodder or for food.(e.g. green peas, green beans, maize for forage) Data for seed element are stored in tonnes (t). Whenever official data were not available, seed figures have been estimated either as a percentage of supply (e.g. eggs for hatching) or by multiplying a seed rate with the area under the crop of the subsequent year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Barley yield (kg per hectare)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Barley yield, measured as kilograms per hectare of harvested land. Production data on relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Crop harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cereal yield (kg per hectare)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cereal yield, measured as kilograms per hectare of harvested land, includes wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded. The FAO allocates production data to the calendar year in which the bulk of the harvest took place. Most of a crop harvested near the end of a year will be used in the following year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.
